displayed_text: Family Member: Right. Doctor: So it’s very common to see cancer cells along the nerves. Family Member: And the nerves came out with the vesicles? Doctor: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Um is it any better that the extra prosthetic extension is a pattern three instead of a four? Doctor: Maybe. Family Member: I’m hoping. I’m looking for a little light of sunshine. Okay. And then the extra nodule that doesn’t say what that was. It just says it had extended out of one, the one positive node. Right? Doctor: So that’s not a ray of sunshine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So node looks like that, actually they’re smaller. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And they can get cancer in them and then cancer can grow out of that a little bit. That’s extra nodule extension. Family Member: Um hum and you don’t know what that’s touching other nodes or other areas of the body?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. Uh, so we just give a once-a-day low dose, and that seems to be enough to keep the potassium normal. But some people don’t like prednisone. It makes them feel weird. It makes them gain weight. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. But I think that’s what I would do next is- now, the way I do that is, the other side effect of these drugs are they’re very expensive. So what we do is, uh, we have a whole group here whose job is, if we decide we’re going to do one or the other, I will call them today, and say, “I want to put you on X.” Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They will go and look at your insurance. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Figure out what X is going to cost. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: What’s the best pharmacy to get it from?

Patient: Um. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it just lets me be aware that I’ve got to be extra careful I’m giving you the chemotherapy. But it could be the one thing that sort of says oh he’s not eligible because he’s got a tube in his body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Or maybe they don’t care one bit. Patient: Um. Doctor: So that’s what D___ and I will work on. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. So I’ll to go - Doctor: Well then let me; I think she’s out here but I know she will have been in touch with you, but I think she wanted me to clear you today to say hey, that she’s still a candidate because his blood tests have improved and acts with – PSA isn’t bad. Okay. Uh are there questions that you guys have? So we talked about diet; we talked about Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But right now they’re going to spend a little bit more time seeing if the trial makes sense for you –

Patient: it I mean an x-ray to look at it that may be even a replacement here or something’s been compromised here or the cancer side? Doctor: Well yeah or if it’s just arthritis then we often just… Patient: I see. Doctor: … we can all just be happy or Patient: Okay. Doctor: At some point you’ll probably get a knee-hip replacement. Patient: Yeah. Well I know that’s true. Doctor: But that’s a whole ‘nother story. But that way if you do call me one day out of the blue, I’m gonna be like yeah we just checked your hip thing remember and it was a couple months ago and you were fine. Patient: Yeah. Okay. Blood work… Doctor: Might as well get it done. Patient: Blood work everything – can I do that with the Zometa too or when we do the Zometa Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: I might toot, but then after that no problems. Doctor: Very good. So it sounds like everything else is fine. Any new medical problems with your heart, lungs, bowels are functioning fine? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay fine. Patient: No. Doctor: So we just got to resolve this social issue. Patient: Yes. Doctor: That’s the biggest thing. Patient: Is it time for me to get up you know. Doctor: Yes, I hear ya. Patient: You know from the biopsy, not by biopsy from my colonoscopy I’ve been asking you about when we wait some more. Doctor: Yeah right yes.

Family Member: Yeah. Thank you Jesus. Doctor: Um hmm. Family Member: But um he was asking me did he ever have an MRI of the prostate lymph nodes. Doctor: Prostate – no, I don’t think so. Family Member: No. Doctor: He had a CAT scan. Family Member: Yeah. Now will that show if there was any problem or would it? Doctor: Well – Family Member: I know MRI show more. Doctor: Well they both can show that. I think it’s more of what are we looking for to do with that. Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: He’s sort of past that.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Huh, so are you finished with that? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. And then so you’re still taking the abiraterone four pills a day? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Huh, the acyclovir is the one that they’ve asked you to take for ten days, probably for this? Huh, the Dulcolax to help for constipation? The Natural Tears now for your eye? The iron pill one, huh, three times a day? Patient: Yep. Well. Doctor: The ibuprofen as needed? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The lisinopril with the water pill in it, one pill a day? Patient: Right. Doctor: And you’ve got your tapazole, huh, methimazole. Doctor: Morphine. You’ve got, huh, fifteen milligrams as needed? Your multivitamin once a day?

Patient: And if I don’t hear nothing, then how long, should I call you? Doctor: Give me a week. Just you know, if you use MyChart, you can give us a call. I’ll just follow up with them. They’re usually pretty good about it. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. That’s it. Doctor: Other question you guys have? Patient: Do you want me to leave so you can talk? Family Member 1: No. But we knew this. We knew that the first line of drugs wasn’t going to last forever and we were going to have to go to a new line of drugs. And when this doesn’t work, we’ll go to the next line. We, you’ve been very honest about that since day one that that this is how it was going to go. Doctor: And you told me you’re holding your own so you’re hanging right in there. Family Member 1: Right. Doctor: You’re still better than when you started. Right? Patient: Yeah. Huh, you said it, well, it’s a concern from one to three hundred and fifty. But you said from the beginning you don’t want it to go over six hundred. Family Member 1: No one said that.

Patient: Oh yeah, yeah. Doctor: Maybe it will cool down a little bit. Patient: Yeah right, yeah. Doctor: But let’s not do it too fast because remember even before this when we tried to get you off of it… Patient: Yeah I had issues. Doctor: You had a major revolt. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So let’s take it really slow. Family Member: The only issue he had he was nervous at first it might be his kidneys he was having a pain on this side, but then it switches to the other side. So I think it’s his back. Patient: I think it’s my back. Family Member: Yea, because it went from… Doctor: Does it hurt now when I push? Patient: No, no, no.

Patient: Maybe twice a day. Doctor: Okay. The Lisinopril five milligrams once a day? Patient: Um hum. Yeah. Doctor: Melatonin. You take two tablets at night for insomnia? Family Member: Actually, that’s- Patient: No. Not every day. Doctor: Metoprolol twenty-five milligrams? Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Senokot, the two to help move your bowels? Family Member: Yes. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Tamsulosin or Flomax once a day?

Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, uh, we could potentially do the hormone therapy and then do the vaccine, also. Okay? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh. Patient: What did you think about that? Because I know you think differently than I do. Doctor: And so the Xtandi trials we have are Xtandi plus, uh, one of the drugs affect kind of the hormone pathways in different ways. Uh, so there’s some reason why they would work together with Xtandi. Uh, one of them is an immune drug itself. Uh, that immune drug, that, that trial, you get either the Xtandi plus the immune drug or just the Xtandi alone, but it requires biopsy. Uh, the other, the other trial we have is Xtandi plus, uh, a drug that affects we think a signal that the cancers can use as an alternative to the hormone signal. So they kind of switch over. So our idea is to block both signals to see if that would help. That, I think you get both drugs, uh, but, again, it also requires a biopsy. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ve got to find out about that. Those are the two I’m going to look at. Okay? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And then I’m going to look at what is the Xtandi going to cost us, and, you know, hopefully within the next two days, I’ll have the answer to all that. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? Family Member: Okay.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: If you know, for medical expenses Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: if it’s getting to be too much let me know, bring it in, and then we’ll consider that. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Alright Family Member: We appreciate you. Thank you for your input. Doctor: Of course. Family Member: Because J___ listens to you. Doctor: Yeah and he’s doing much better too. Family Member: Yes, he is. Doctor: So the cancer meds do you have enough or are you gonna need a refill. Family Member: We have one refill left. When do we come back here?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Ummm, they compare it to the CAT scan. The CAT scan says there maybe new but more intense. Uh, but bone scans trump CAT scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm, so, we could technically say that that’s stable. Um. They comment more about your jaw this time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: They’re saying that it’s more intense. Uh, and they’re saying this could be more cancer then, you know, dental disease. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. It’s hard to say that because basically a bone scan is just about inflammation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so, if you had dental work or there’s inflammation from troubles related to the Xgeva. That would light up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, if it’s the cancer that’s really causing it, then that, that would cause it to light up. Patient: Okay.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Retired: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Retired

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: They ain’t doin’ any… (pause4sec) Doctor: And pain wise I have to give you the one hundred eighty right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I think you’ve reminded me after now enough that (laughs) Healthcare Professional: I think he’s on morphine sixty? Doctor: Is he authorized for the Okay. Patient: Oh out here? Doctor: No or when you go over for treatment you can hand it to your nurse Patient: Okay. Doctor: and they can make all the schedule for you. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So you don’t have to wait here. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that’s a reasonable study for ya, but you know, again, you would Patient: Screw a weekend, yeah. About an hour and half of life. Doctor: Um. So, that, you know, again, the vitamin C has to be given here because we’re paying for it. Patient: Right. Doctor: The other study that right now, the-the call that I got interrupted was about your eligibility for a phase one study. Uh, that is a first in human of a brand new drug that we’re evaluating only in prostate cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, So, it is also an infusion, and I’ll have to pull it up. Uh, I don’t know how often you have to be there, but it – there is a slot available. It says that, uh, it has to be people with bone disease only. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Um, they used to say that you had to have only Abiraterone or Enzalutamide. Uh, but now, they have broadened it, that if you have had Abiraterone AND Enzalutamide, you can participate. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. So, that one would be an option for you. Um. It’s uncharted territory. Patient: No chemo drug, though?
